name: commit
description: Smart git commit with conventional commit messages
instructions:
Create a git commit following these steps:

1. Run `git status` and `git diff --staged` to see what's changed
2. Analyze the changes and determine:
   - Type: feat, fix, docs, test, refactor, style, chore
   - Scope: affected module/component
   - Breaking changes: if any
3. Create a commit message following this format:
   ```
   <type>(<scope>): <short description>
   
   <detailed description if needed>
   
   <breaking changes if any>
   
   ðŸ¤– Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)
   
   Co-Authored-By: Claude Sonnet 4.5 <noreply@anthropic.com>
   ```
4. Run `git add` for any unstaged files that should be included
5. Execute the commit
6. Ask user if they want to push

IMPORTANT:
- Keep the first line under 72 characters
- Focus on WHY, not WHAT (code shows what)
- Be specific and descriptive
- Only commit when user explicitly asks or confirms
